I'm Debbie Elliott.
In Baghdad today, the commander of U.S.
forces in Iraq, General David Petraeus announced a new push to root out al-Qaida strongholds.

We have in fact just launched offensive operations in a number of areas around Baghdad in particular to go in to areas that were sanctuaries in the past of al-Qaida and from which they have launched car bombs and so forth.
General Petraeus conferred today with Defense Secretary Gates who was visiting Baghdad.
Secretary Gates also met with Iraqi leaders urging them to move more quickly toward political reconciliation.
The prospect of reconciliation seemed to dim this week when a major Shiite shrine in Samara was bombed for the second time in 16 months.
Several Sunni mosques have been targeted in apparent reprisal attacks.
Last year's bombing in Samara sparked a surge in sectarian fighting in Iraq and U.S.
officials have said another such attack would be their nightmare scenario.
Here to talk with us about Wednesday's bombing and the security situation there is Major General Benjamin Mixon, the U.S.
commander for Northern Iraq.
Thank you for being with us, General.
Thank you.
Do you know who's responsible for Wednesday's bombing?
Maj.
Gen.

MIXON: I do know that the Security Guard Force that was present at the mosque and had responsible has been detained by the Iraqi government and I'm sure from that we will learn specifically who is responsible.
So there is a sense that the very people who were in charge of guarding this mosque could have been part of the group that attacked it?
Maj.
Gen.
MIXON: Well, we don't know that for sure.
But certainly they had the responsible.
They were present at the time of the bombing.
There were no shots fired to cause them to flee the scene so it has to be investigated.
The Iraqis are doing this and I'm sure they will find out ultimately who's responsible.
Who was in charge of protecting the shrine?
Maj.
Gen.
MIXON: There are Iraqi security forces located at every shrine and mosque that are of significance around the country.
The Iraqis do this, of course, obviously these are holy places that we respect and they guard them.
So these are guard forces that are trained to guard these particular areas.
There had been reports as well that some other mosques have been attacked, some Sunni mosques in reprisal for this.
And witnesses are saying that security forces are not responding to those attacks.
What does this whole picture say about the ability of Iraqi forces to provide security?
Maj.
Gen.
MIXON: Oh, I have not seen anything like that in my area of responsibility.
What I have seen is Iraqi security forces from the prime minister on down went immediately to Samara.
They moved additional forces into that area.
I was in Samara today, meeting with those security forces, and they have the situation in Samara in the surrounding areas well enhanced.
Trump is just a bad brand for Dallas.
I don't want to see Dallas associated with that.
We left the car and stepped on stage at a Roman-style amphitheater large enough to seat thousands.
He's raised $605 million roughly.
And to put that in perspective, that's about half of what the two presidential candidates four years ago spent on everything from the primaries through the conventions to the election.
Do you have any idea where the money is coming from, where Obama is getting his support?
Well, the campaign makes a big deal about how small the average donation is.
Under a hundred dollars this month, $86 overall, is what they say.
There had been some questions raised, mostly by McCain's campaign, about people sneaking in illegal money through these small contributions.
And Obama has not released details of small donors.
He doesn't have to because they're so small.
But overall the questions amount to just a really small percentage of the vast amounts of money he's raised.
NPR's Peter Overby.
Peter, thanks very much.
Thank you.

Joni's ""Blue"" was number one.
